TRADE ITEMS.
(The Editor will be glad to receive from the trade this column any items of general interest.)
TRADE CHANGES.—Messrs. Holmes & Webster, timber merchants, joiners and builders, Ashton-under-Lyne, have dissolved partnership. Debts by Mr. Holmes, who continues the business.
MESSRS. A. Holstead & Son, joiners and builders, West Parade, Halifax, have dissolved partnership. Debts by Mr. Edwin Holstead, who continues the business.
MESSRS. ACLAND & ANDREWS, of Wandsworth, Soho, are retiring from the timber trade.
OBITUARY.—The death is announced of Mr. John Smith, of the firm of Wheatman & Smith (Limited), saw manufacturers, Russell Street Works, Sheffield.
ACCIDENT IN A PORT GLASGOW TIMBER YARD.—Patrick M'Guire, 19 years of age, an assistant fitter, while working upon a crane in the yard of Messrs. Robert Duncan & Co., had his arm broken, and received other serious injuries, by a heavy plank falling upon him. He was removed to Greenock Infirmary.
MR. THOS. WILSON, of Greek Street, has announced that he has now completed and at his Wandsworth Street, where he has put in a very complete saw-mill plant. At his Wandsworth premises he has erected large drying sheds, and is thus enabled to continue his special feature of selling thoroughly seasoned woods.
KING'S LYNN.—A cargo of partly square fir round Norway fir mining timber is offered for sale at King's Lynn.
MR. JOHN DIXON, who has had a very long experience as manager of the Avonmouth and other docks, has been appointed traffic manager at the Sharpness Docks. With a wide knowledge of the timber trade, Mr. Dixon will no doubt be able to considerably increase of traffic of this description at Gloucester.
THE DEPRESSION IN TRADE.—The carriage works of the London and North-Western Railway Company at Wolverton, employing 2,500 hands, commenced short time last week. The time lost will be equivalent to one day per week.

[MARCH 7, 1885.
THE GAZETTE.
FAILURES AND ARRANGEMENTS.
[It must not be overlooked that in many cases creditors whose names are published in these lists hold security for their debts, sometimes for the full amount.]
JOHN FLINT, builder, 216 and 218, High Street, Lewisham.—The statement of affairs filed by the debtor discloses gross liabilities of £5,593 11s. 11d.; unsecured creditors, £4,865; fully secured creditors, £556 15s. 8d.; fully secured creditors, other liabilities, £151 7s. 6d.; and liability on bills, £20 8s. 9d. The debtor estimates the value of the securities held by the fully secured creditors at the amount of their claims, and there are otherwise no assets. The debtor appears to have commenced business without capital in 1869, and was made bankrupt four years later, but paid no dividend, and obtained his discharge shortly afterwards. A meeting of creditors was held on the 27th February last, at the offices of the Official Receiver, Mr. Shirtcliffe occupying the chair. No resolution was passed, and the debtor accordingly was adjudicated a bankrupt, the Official Receiver being constituted trustee. The following is a list of the principal creditors :—

THOMAS AYRES.—The first meeting of the creditors in this case (reported last week) was held on Monday, before Mr. Wreford, Assistant Receiver. The debtor, described as of 5, Eldon Street, Finsbury, builder, returned his unsecured debts at £2,412 11s. 4d., and assets, £7,872 16s.; thus showing an estimated surplus of £4,460 4s. 8d., subject to realization. The Official Receiver reported as follows:—"The debtor states that he commenced business in September, 1882, with about £100, and carried the business on till December last. He attributes his failure to the seizure and sale of his plant, &c., and furniture under executions by creditors. He states that he has not kept by creditors. He states that he has not kept any books of account. The securities held by creditors are stated to consist of mortgages and charges on houses and shops built by the debtor, the value of which is estimated by him at £10,565, and building agreements in respect of finished and unfinished houses, estimated at £11,777. The 'other property,' £300, is stated to consist of moneys due to the debtor under two building contracts. It appearing from the preliminary examination of the debtor that the assets were not likely to exceed £300, the Court made an order for the summary administration of the estate. Upon examination by Mr. Ward, who appeared for the creditors, the debtor stated that several executions had been issued against his estate, the first of them issued against his goods under last, at the suit towards the end of County was also an execution in the Edmonton County Court at the suit of Messrs. Bray & Co., under which they recovered about £60. The property was bought of Mr. Easterby, and he had never been in business under a bill of sale, and had not kept any books. He never had a cash book, and used to pay his men every week. He did not keep a wages book, but had a cash account of his expenditure and receipts. The surplus of his assets over his debts fully secured
